name: XVerExtensionSubstanceDefinition
title: Cross-Version Extension for FHIR R5:SubstanceDefinition compared to FHIR R4
description: SubstanceDefinition does not exist in target and has no mapping

element.short: The detailed description of a substance, typically at a level beyond what is used for prescribing
element.definition: SubstanceDefinition does not exist in target and has no mapping

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.short: Unique id for inter-element referencing
element.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

slicing.description: Extensions are always sliced by (at least) url

element.short: Additional content defined by implementations
element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. To make the use of extensions safe and managable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.short: identifies the meaning of the extension
element.definition: Source of the definition for the extension code - a logical name or a URL.
element.comment: The definition may point directly to a computable or human-readable definition of the extensibility codes, or it may be a logical URI as declared in some other specification. The definition SHALL be a URI for the Structure Definition defining the extension.

element.short: Value of extension
element.definition: Value of extension - must be one of a constrained set of the data types (see [Extensibility](extensibility.html) for a list).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: A business level version identifier of the substance
Status of substance within the catalogue e.g. active, retired
A categorization, high level e.g. polymer or nucleic acid, or food, chemical, biological, or lower e.g. polymer linear or branch chain, or type of impurity
element.definition: A high level categorization, e.g. polymer or nucleic acid, or food, chemical, biological, or a lower level such as the general types of polymer (linear or branch chain) or type of impurity (process related or contaminant).

element.short: If the substance applies to human or veterinary use
The quality standard, established benchmark, to which substance complies (e.g. USP/NF, BP)
element.definition: The quality standard, established benchmark, to which substance complies (e.g. USP/NF, Ph. Eur, JP, BP, Company Standard).

element.short: Textual description of the substance
Supporting literature
Textual comment about the substance's catalogue or registry record
The entity that creates, makes, produces or fabricates the substance
element.definition: The entity that creates, makes, produces or fabricates the substance. This is a set of potential manufacturers but is not necessarily comprehensive.

element.short: An entity that is the source for the substance. It may be different from the manufacturer
element.definition: An entity that is the source for the substance. It may be different from the manufacturer. Supplier is synonymous to a distributor.

element.short: Moiety, for structural modifications
General specifications for this substance
General specifications for this substance
General information detailing this substance
The average mass of a molecule of a compound
element.definition: The average mass of a molecule of a compound compared to 1/12 the mass of carbon 12 and calculated as the sum of the atomic weights of the constituent atoms.

element.short: Structural information
Names applicable to this substance
A link between this substance and another
element.definition: A link between this substance and another, with details of the relationship.

element.short: Data items specific to nucleic acids
Data items specific to polymers
Data items specific to proteins
Material or taxonomic/anatomical source
element.definition: Material or taxonomic/anatomical source for the substance.

element.short: The detailed description of a substance, typically at a level beyond what is used for prescribing
element.definition: SubstanceDefinition does not exist in target and has no mapping

element.short: A business level version identifier of the substance
Status of substance within the catalogue e.g. active, retired

binding.description: The lifecycle status of an artifact.

element.short: A categorization, high level e.g. polymer or nucleic acid, or food, chemical, biological, or lower e.g. polymer linear or branch chain, or type of impurity
element.definition: A high level categorization, e.g. polymer or nucleic acid, or food, chemical, biological, or a lower level such as the general types of polymer (linear or branch chain) or type of impurity (process related or contaminant).

element.short: If the substance applies to human or veterinary use

binding.description: Applicable domain for this product (e.g. human, veterinary).

element.short: The quality standard, established benchmark, to which substance complies (e.g. USP/NF, BP)
element.definition: The quality standard, established benchmark, to which substance complies (e.g. USP/NF, Ph. Eur, JP, BP, Company Standard).

binding.description: The quality standard, established benchmark, to which a substance complies

element.short: Textual description of the substance
Supporting literature
Textual comment about the substance's catalogue or registry record
The entity that creates, makes, produces or fabricates the substance
element.definition: The entity that creates, makes, produces or fabricates the substance. This is a set of potential manufacturers but is not necessarily comprehensive.

element.short: An entity that is the source for the substance. It may be different from the manufacturer
element.definition: An entity that is the source for the substance. It may be different from the manufacturer. Supplier is synonymous to a distributor.

element.short: Moiety, for structural modifications
Role that the moiety is playing
Identifier by which this moiety substance is known
Textual name for this moiety substance
Stereochemistry type

binding.description: The optical rotation type of a substance.

element.short: Optical activity type

binding.description: The optical rotation type of a substance.

element.short: Molecular formula for this moiety (e.g. with the Hill system)
element.definition: Molecular formula for this moiety of this substance, typically using the Hill system.

element.short: Quantitative value for this moiety
The measurement type of the quantitative value
element.definition: The measurement type of the quantitative value. In capturing the actual relative amounts of substances or molecular fragments it may be necessary to indicate whether the amount refers to, for example, a mole ratio or weight ratio.

binding.description: The relationship between two substance types.

element.short: General specifications for this substance
The method used to find the characterization e.g. HPLC
element.definition: The method used to elucidate the characterization of the drug substance. Example: HPLC.

binding.description: The method used to elucidate the characterization of the drug substance.

element.short: Describes the nature of the chemical entity and explains, for instance, whether this is a base or a salt form
The description or justification in support of the interpretation of the data file
The data produced by the analytical instrument or a pictorial representation of that data. Examples: a JCAMP, JDX, or ADX file, or a chromatogram or spectrum analysis
General specifications for this substance
A code expressing the type of property

binding.description: This value set includes all observable entity codes from SNOMED CT - provided as an exemplar value set.

element.short: A value for the property
General information detailing this substance
The average mass of a molecule of a compound
element.definition: The average mass of a molecule of a compound compared to 1/12 the mass of carbon 12 and calculated as the sum of the atomic weights of the constituent atoms.

element.short: The method by which the weight was determined
element.definition: The method by which the molecular weight was determined.

binding.description: The method by which the substance weight was measured.

element.short: Type of molecular weight e.g. exact, average, weight average
element.definition: Type of molecular weight such as exact, average (also known as. number average), weight average.

binding.description: The type of substance weight measurement.

element.short: Used to capture quantitative values for a variety of elements
element.definition: Used to capture quantitative values for a variety of elements. If only limits are given, the arithmetic mean would be the average. If only a single definite value for a given element is given, it would be captured in this field.

element.short: Structural information
Stereochemistry type

binding.description: The optical rotation type of a substance.

element.short: Optical activity type

binding.description: The optical rotation type of a substance.

element.short: An expression which states the number and type of atoms present in a molecule of a substance
Specified per moiety according to the Hill system
element.definition: Specified per moiety according to the Hill system, i.e. first C, then H, then alphabetical, each moiety separated by a dot.

element.short: The molecular weight or weight range
element.definition: The molecular weight or weight range (for proteins, polymers or nucleic acids).

element.short: The method used to find the structure e.g. X-ray, NMR
element.definition: The method used to elucidate the structure of the drug substance. Examples: X-ray, NMR, Peptide mapping, Ligand binding assay.

binding.description: The method used to elucidate the structure of the drug substance.

element.short: Source of information for the structure
element.definition: The source of information about the structure.

element.short: A depiction of the structure of the substance
The kind of structural representation (e.g. full, partial)

binding.description: A format of a substance representation.

element.short: The structural representation as a text string in a standard format
The format of the representation e.g. InChI, SMILES, MOLFILE (note: not the physical file format)
element.definition: The format of the representation e.g. InChI, SMILES, MOLFILE, CDX, SDF, PDB, mmCIF. The logical content type rather than the physical file format of a document.

binding.description: A format of a substance representation.

element.short: An attachment with the structural representation e.g. a structure graphic or AnIML file
element.definition: An attached file with the structural representation e.g. a molecular structure graphic of the substance, a JCAMP or AnIML file.

element.short: Names applicable to this substance
The actual name
Name type e.g. 'systematic',  'scientific, 'brand'
element.definition: Name type, for example 'systematic',  'scientific, 'brand'.

binding.description: The type of a name given to a substance.

element.short: The status of the name e.g. 'current', 'proposed'
element.definition: The status of the name, for example 'current', 'proposed'.

binding.description: The lifecycle status of an artifact.

element.short: If this is the preferred name for this substance
Human language that the name is written in

binding.description: IETF language tag for a human language

element.short: The use context of this name e.g. as an active ingredient or as a food colour additive
element.definition: The use context of this name for example if there is a different name a drug active ingredient as opposed to a food colour additive.

binding.description: The use context of a substance name for example if there is a different name when used as a drug active ingredient as opposed to a food colour additive.

element.short: The jurisdiction where this name applies

binding.description: Jurisdiction codes

element.short: A synonym of this particular name, by which the substance is also known
A translation for this name into another human language
Details of the official nature of this name
Which authority uses this official name

binding.description: An authority that officates substance names.

element.short: The status of the official name, for example 'draft', 'active'
element.definition: The status of the official name, for example 'draft', 'active', 'retired'.

binding.description: The lifecycle status of an artifact.

element.short: Date of official name change
element.definition: Date of the official name change.

element.short: Supporting literature
A link between this substance and another
element.definition: A link between this substance and another, with details of the relationship.

element.short: A pointer to another substance, as a resource or a representational code
element.definition: A pointer to another substance, as a resource or just a representational code.

element.short: For example "salt to parent", "active moiety"
element.definition: For example "salt to parent", "active moiety", "starting material", "polymorph", "impurity of".

binding.description: The relationship between two substance types.

element.short: For example where an enzyme strongly bonds with a particular substance, this is a defining relationship for that enzyme, out of several possible relationships
element.definition: For example where an enzyme strongly bonds with a particular substance, this is a defining relationship for that enzyme, out of several possible substance relationships.

element.short: A numeric factor for the relationship, e.g. that a substance salt has some percentage of active substance in relation to some other
element.definition: A numeric factor for the relationship, for instance to express that the salt of a substance has some percentage of the active substance in relation to some other.

element.short: For use when the numeric has an uncertain range
An operator for the amount, for example "average", "approximately", "less than"

binding.description: The relationship between two substance types.

element.short: Supporting literature
Data items specific to nucleic acids
Data items specific to polymers
Data items specific to proteins
Material or taxonomic/anatomical source
element.definition: Material or taxonomic/anatomical source for the substance.

element.short: Classification of the origin of the raw material. e.g. cat hair is an Animal source type
element.definition: A classification that provides the origin of the raw material. Example: cat hair would be an Animal source type.

binding.description: A classification that provides the origin of the substance raw material.

element.short: The genus of an organism e.g. the Latin epithet of the plant/animal scientific name
element.definition: The genus of an organism, typically referring to the Latin epithet of the genus element of the plant/animal scientific name.

binding.description: The genus of an organism, typically referring to the Latin epithet of the genus element of the plant/animal scientific name.

element.short: The species of an organism e.g. the Latin epithet of the species of the plant/animal
element.definition: The species of an organism, typically referring to the Latin epithet of the species of the plant/animal.

binding.description: A species of origin a substance raw material.

element.short: An anatomical origin of the source material within an organism

binding.description: An anatomical origin of the source material within an organism.

element.short: The country or countries where the material is harvested

binding.description: Jurisdiction codes
